title.text: Tweester at SemEval-2016 Task 4: Sentiment Analysis in Twitter using Semantic-Affective Model Adaptation

abstractContent.text: We describe our submission to SemEval2016 Task 4: Sentiment Analysis in Twitter.
The proposed system ranked first for the sub-task B.
Our system comprises of multiple independent models such as neural networks, semantic-affective models and topic modeling that are combined in a probabilistic way.
The novelty of the system is the employment of a topic modeling approach in order to adapt the semantic-affective space for each tweet.
In addition, significant enhancements were made in the main system dealing with the data pre-processing and feature extraction including the employment of word embeddings.
Each model is used to predict a tweet's sentiment (positive, negative or neutral) and a late fusion scheme is adopted for the final decision.

introductionContent.text: Nowadays, the usage of social networks such as Twitter dominates the daily communication of hundreds of millions of people around the world.
People often share opinions and express their feelings about various topics through social networks.
Tasks such as opinion mining and sentiment analysis have become very popular, since they can capture a large portion of the public opinion.
The sentiment analysis of tweets was applied in various domains, such as commerce (, disaster management ( or health.
This task is especially challenging due to the terse and informal writing style, the semantic diversity of content, as well as the often "unconventional" grammar and orthography.
Many computational systems like those submitted to) incorporate bag-of-words models with Twitter-specific features like hashtags and emoticons.
Word embeddings obtained from large amounts of tweets are used under the scope of an unsupervised approach for sentiment analysis.
Additionally, deep learning models have recently become very popular for Twitter sentiment analysis.

Topic modeling approaches for sentiment analysis can also be found in literature, e.g., In this paper, we present systems submitted to the) that deal with the sentiment analysis of tweets on the sentence level.
The submitted systems are based on the fusion of the different classifiers.

Specifically, 1) we enhanced the system submitted by to the SemEval 2014 Task 9 (), 2) we used the open-source system submitted by to the), 3) we trained a convolutional neural network on a large amount of unlabelled Twitter data, 4) we developed a system based on topic modeling and 5) we trained a classifier using word embeddings as features.

Our system was submitted on two subtasks, namely subtask A (message polarity classification) and subtask B (tweet classification according to a two-point scale) and ranked in the fifth 1 and the first place, respectively.
